summary.long: Song Of Solomon is a book of the Old Testament.

verses.text: The Song of Songs, which is Solomon's.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Let him kiss me with the kisses of his mouth!
For your love is better than wine;
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
I am very dark, but lovely,
    O daughters of Jerusalem,
like the tents of Kedar,
    like the curtains of Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Do not gaze at me because I am dark,
    because the sun has looked upon me.
My mother's sons were angry with me;
    they made me keeper of the vineyards,
    but my own vineyard I have not kept!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Tell me, you whom my soul loves,
    where you pasture your flock,
    where you make it lie down at noon;
for why should I be like one who veils herself
    beside the flocks of your companions?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If you do not know,
    O most beautiful among women,
follow in the tracks of the flock,
    and pasture your young goats
    beside the shepherds' tents.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I compare you, my love,
    to a mare among Pharaoh's chariots.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your cheeks are lovely with ornaments,
    your neck with strings of jewels.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
We will make for you ornaments of gold,
    studded with silver.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
While the king was on his couch,
    my nard gave forth its fragrance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My beloved is to me a sachet of myrrh
    that lies between my breasts.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My beloved is to me a cluster of henna blossoms
    in the vineyards of Engedi.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Behold, you are beautiful, my beloved, truly delightful.
Our couch is green;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
the beams of our house are cedar;
    our rafters are pine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I am a rose of Sharon,
    a lily of the valleys.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As a lily among brambles,
    so is my love among the young women.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As an apple tree among the trees of the forest,
    so is my beloved among the young men.
With great delight I sat in his shadow,
    and his fruit was sweet to my taste.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He brought me to the banqueting house,
    and his banner over me was love.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
His left hand is under my head,
    and his right hand embraces me!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I adjure you, O daughters of Jerusalem,
    by the gazelles or the does of the field,
that you not stir up or awaken love
    until it pleases.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The voice of my beloved!
    Behold, he comes,
leaping over the mountains,
    bounding over the hills.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My beloved is like a gazelle
    or a young stag.
Behold, there he stands
    behind our wall,
gazing through the windows,
    looking through the lattice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My beloved speaks and says to me:
“Arise, my love, my beautiful one,
    and come away,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
for behold, the winter is past;
    the rain is over and gone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The flowers appear on the earth,
    the time of singing has come,
and the voice of the turtledove
    is heard in our land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The fig tree ripens its figs,
    and the vines are in blossom;
    they give forth fragrance.
Arise, my love, my beautiful one,
    and come away.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Catch the foxes for us,
    the little foxes
that spoil the vineyards,
    for our vineyards are in blossom.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My beloved is mine, and I am his;
    he grazes among the lilies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Until the day breathes
    and the shadows flee,
turn, my beloved, be like a gazelle
    or a young stag on cleft mountains.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
I will rise now and go about the city,
    in the streets and in the squares;
I will seek him whom my soul loves.
    I sought him, but found him not.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The watchmen found me
    as they went about in the city.
“Have you seen him whom my soul loves?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Scarcely had I passed them
    when I found him whom my soul loves.
I held him, and would not let him go
    until I had brought him into my mother's house,
    and into the chamber of her who conceived me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I adjure you, O daughters of Jerusalem,
    by the gazelles or the does of the field,
that you not stir up or awaken love
    until it pleases.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
What is that coming up from the wilderness
    like columns of smoke,
perfumed with myrrh and frankincense,
    with all the fragrant powders of a merchant?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Behold, it is the litter of Solomon!
Around it are sixty mighty men,
    some of the mighty men of Israel,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
all of them wearing swords
    and expert in war,
each with his sword at his thigh,
    against terror by night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
King Solomon made himself a carriage
    from the wood of Lebanon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He made its posts of silver,
    its back of gold, its seat of purple;
its interior was inlaid with love
    by the daughters of Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Go out, O daughters of Zion,
    and look upon King Solomon,
with the crown with which his mother crowned him
    on the day of his wedding,
    on the day of the gladness of his heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Behold, you are beautiful, my love,
    behold, you are beautiful!
Your eyes are doves
    behind your veil.
Your hair is like a flock of goats
    leaping down the slopes of Gilead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your teeth are like a flock of shorn ewes
    that have come up from the washing,
all of which bear twins,
    and not one among them has lost its young.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your lips are like a scarlet thread,
    and your mouth is lovely.
Your cheeks are like halves of a pomegranate
    behind your veil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your neck is like the tower of David,
    built in rows of stone;
on it hang a thousand shields,
    all of them shields of warriors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your two breasts are like two fawns,
    twins of a gazelle,
    that graze among the lilies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Until the day breathes
    and the shadows flee,
I will go away to the mountain of myrrh
    and the hill of frankincense.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You are altogether beautiful, my love;
    there is no flaw in you.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
How beautiful is your love, my sister, my bride!
    How much better is your love than wine,
    and the fragrance of your oils than any spice!
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
A garden locked is my sister, my bride,
    a spring locked, a fountain sealed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your shoots are an orchard of pomegranates
    with all choicest fruits,
    henna with nard,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
nard and saffron, calamus and cinnamon,
    with all trees of frankincense,
myrrh and aloes,
    with all choice spices—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
a garden fountain, a well of living water,
    and flowing streams from Lebanon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Awake, O north wind,
    and come, O south wind!
Blow upon my garden,
    let its spices flow.
Let my beloved come to his garden,
    and eat its choicest fruits.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I came to my garden, my sister, my bride,
    I gathered my myrrh with my spice,
    I ate my honeycomb with my honey,
    I drank my wine with my milk.
Eat, friends, drink,
    and be drunk with love!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I slept, but my heart was awake.
A sound! My beloved is knocking.
“Open to me, my sister, my love,
    my dove, my perfect one,
for my head is wet with dew,
    my locks with the drops of the night.”
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
My beloved put his hand to the latch,
    and my heart was thrilled within me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I arose to open to my beloved,
    and my hands dripped with myrrh,
my fingers with liquid myrrh,
    on the handles of the bolt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I opened to my beloved,
    but my beloved had turned and gone.
My soul failed me when he spoke.
I sought him, but found him not;
    I called him, but he gave no answer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The watchmen found me
    as they went about in the city;
they beat me, they bruised me,
    they took away my veil,
    those watchmen of the walls.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I adjure you, O daughters of Jerusalem,
    if you find my beloved,
that you tell him
    I am sick with love.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
What is your beloved more than another beloved,
    O most beautiful among women?
What is your beloved more than another beloved,
    that you thus adjure us?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My beloved is radiant and ruddy,
    distinguished among ten thousand.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
His eyes are like doves
    beside streams of water,
bathed in milk,
    sitting beside a full pool.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His cheeks are like beds of spices,
    mounds of sweet-smelling herbs.
His lips are lilies,
    dripping liquid myrrh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His arms are rods of gold,
    set with jewels.
His body is polished ivory,
    bedecked with sapphires.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His legs are alabaster columns,
    set on bases of gold.
His appearance is like Lebanon,
    choice as the cedars.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His mouth is most sweet,
    and he is altogether desirable.
This is my beloved and this is my friend,
    O daughters of Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Where has your beloved gone,
    O most beautiful among women?
Where has your beloved turned,
    that we may seek him with you?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My beloved has gone down to his garden
    to the beds of spices,
to graze in the gardens
    and to gather lilies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I am my beloved's and my beloved is mine;
    he grazes among the lilies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You are beautiful as Tirzah, my love,
    lovely as Jerusalem,
    awesome as an army with banners.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Turn away your eyes from me,
    for they overwhelm me—
Your hair is like a flock of goats
    leaping down the slopes of Gilead.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Your cheeks are like halves of a pomegranate
    behind your veil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
There are sixty queens and eighty concubines,
    and virgins without number.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My dove, my perfect one, is the only one,
    the only one of her mother,
    pure to her who bore her.
The young women saw her and called her blessed;
    the queens and concubines also, and they praised her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Who is this who looks down like the dawn,
    beautiful as the moon, bright as the sun,
    awesome as an army with banners?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I went down to the nut orchard
    to look at the blossoms of the valley,
to see whether the vines had budded,
    whether the pomegranates were in bloom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Before I was aware, my desire set me
    among the chariots of my kinsman, a prince.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Return, return, O Shulammite,
    return, return, that we may look upon you.
Why should you look upon the Shulammite,
    as upon a dance before two armies?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
How beautiful are your feet in sandals,
    O noble daughter!
Your rounded thighs are like jewels,
    the work of a master hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your navel is a rounded bowl
    that never lacks mixed wine.
Your belly is a heap of wheat,
    encircled with lilies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your two breasts are like two fawns,
    twins of a gazelle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your neck is like an ivory tower.
Your eyes are pools in Heshbon,
    by the gate of Bath-rabbim.
Your nose is like a tower of Lebanon,
    which looks toward Damascus.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
How beautiful and pleasant you are,
    O loved one, with all your delights!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your stature is like a palm tree,
    and your breasts are like its clusters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I say I will climb the palm tree
    and lay hold of its fruit.
Oh may your breasts be like clusters of the vine,
    and the scent of your breath like apples,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
and your mouth like the best wine.
It goes down smoothly for my beloved,
    gliding over lips and teeth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I am my beloved's,
    and his desire is for me.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
let us go out early to the vineyards
    and see whether the vines have budded,
whether the grape blossoms have opened
    and the pomegranates are in bloom.
There I will give you my love.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The mandrakes give forth fragrance,
    and beside our doors are all choice fruits,
new as well as old,
    which I have laid up for you, O my beloved.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Oh that you were like a brother to me
    who nursed at my mother's breasts!
If I found you outside, I would kiss you,
    and none would despise me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I would lead you and bring you
    into the house of my mother—
    she who used to teach me.
I would give you spiced wine to drink,
    the juice of my pomegranate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His left hand is under my head,
    and his right hand embraces me!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I adjure you, O daughters of Jerusalem,
    that you not stir up or awaken love
    until it pleases.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who is that coming up from the wilderness,
    leaning on her beloved?
Under the apple tree I awakened you.
There your mother was in labor with you;
    there she who bore you was in labor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Set me as a seal upon your heart,
    as a seal upon your arm,
for love is strong as death,
    jealousy is fierce as the grave.
Its flashes are flashes of fire,
    the very flame of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Many waters cannot quench love,
    neither can floods drown it.
If a man offered for love
    all the wealth of his house,
    he would be utterly despised.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
We have a little sister,
    and she has no breasts.
What shall we do for our sister
    on the day when she is spoken for?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If she is a wall,
    we will build on her a battlement of silver,
but if she is a door,
    we will enclose her with boards of cedar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I was a wall,
    and my breasts were like towers;
then I was in his eyes
    as one who finds peace.
verses.speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

verses.text:
Make haste, my beloved,
    and be like a gazelle
or a young stag
    on the mountains of spices.
verses.speaker: Narrator
